text: I've been living with HIV since 1995
duty those days it was terrible because
we didn't have assistants like we have
right now from America but now i'm okay
i'm living happy i'm taking my drugs
every day this is Donald G McNeil jr.
reporting from Uganda every member of
the stigma lyst band is HIV positive
antiretroviral drugs paid for by the
United States and other donors are
keeping them alive but the battle
against aids in the third world is
beginning to fall apart millions have
been saved but the money is running out
while middle-income countries like India
and Brazil may be able to save
themselves the future here in the heart
of Africa looks bleak okay that i found
out i was HIV positive after i started
falling sick my husband had died
sometime back after he died I started
falling sick and went to the hospital
dinna Vance come a coma came to stay
with her cousins in Kampala hoping to
get free treatment her kidneys are
failing she's so weak she can barely
walk her time is running out but the
hospitals here even the one where her
cousin works can't take on any new
patients
when they tested her they found she was
HIV positive and they told us to go for
what a RVs but they could not provide
them and when you move around the
clinics they need what they need money
which is not their donors pay for ninety
percent of drugs in poor countries
almost all it bought through PEPFAR
which was set up by the Bush
administration or through the Global
Fund which is international but the
Global Fund is having trouble raising
money and the Obama administration is
concentrating its foreign aid for help
on problems that are cheaper to treat
like malaria pneumonia and diarrhea more
lives may be safe for those taxpayer
dollars but it means PEPFAR s budget is
no longer growing Uganda has been hit
hardest ironically because it did such a
good job of getting lots of patients on
treatment quickly it's the first country
in Africa to reach its limits it will
not be the last dr. David a pulley
Uganda's top aides official divides the
epidemic in Africa into four decades the
first was death everywhere in the second
drugs were discovered but only available
in rich countries the third coming up to
the present was the decade of hope donor
stepped in and made drugs available
across the continent how the fourth will
be remembered is being defined today
seeing you learn the tip of the iceberg
of what we expect to see in the
countries it is a dilemma in this first
decade for all of us Wayne Uganda the
American people the global people what
do we do money is not the whole problem
sciences failed to know AIDS vaccine is
on the horizon nor the microbe aside nor
is a female condom that women will
accept and people have also failed not
enough for practicing ABC abstain be
faithful use a condom or the new fourth
C circumcision for every 1,000 people
put on drugs 2500 are getting infected
in spite of people seeing a lot of
people dying
a lot of suffering with AIDS people have
kept on they have not changed their
behavior and that's why they are they
are still dying of HIV AIDS at the windy
community hospital on Uganda's
mountainous border the drugs didn't
arrive until 2007 but in three years the
hospital has gotten them to thousands of
the local people even into pygmy
settlements but now they're running out
I think we have to give antivirals to
people we have a moral you know moral
necessity Willie to give life-saving
drugs that are available to people who
need them but you do wonder what's going
to happen if these drugs get stopped
because from a sort of medical point of
view there'll be problems with
resistance huge problems of drug
resistance so that if they ever get
started again we'll have double problems
ready worldwide the numbers are grim
about 33 million people are infected
with HIV after a Herculean effort by
donors led by the United States only
about four million are on treatment even
under optimistic fundraising projections
by five years from now only about 10
million will be treated that's not
nearly enough new research shows that
treating everyone as early as possible
could lower infection rates but that
idea is frighteningly expensive it is
very sad that people have to choose what
should or should not kill patients
you can't say a disease killing patients
but it is expensive death therefore we
are going to prevent ship deaths I don't
think this is a humanitarian approach or

balance on her family knowing what a
